metadata.title: During Aspergillus infection, neutrophil, monocyte-derived DC, and plasmacytoid DC 1 enhance innate immune defense through CXCR3-dependent crosstalk 2 3

abstract.text: Aspergillus fumigatus, a ubiquitous mold, is a common cause of invasive aspergillosis (IA) in 29 immunocompromised patients. Host defense against IA relies on lung-infiltrating neutrophils and 30 monocyte-derived dendritic cells (Mo-DCs). Here, we demonstrate that plasmacytoid dendritic 31 cells (pDCs), which are prototypically anti-viral cells, participate in innate immune crosstalk 32 underlying mucosal antifungal immunity. Aspergillus-infected murine Mo-DCs and neutrophils 33 recruited pDCs to the lung by releasing the CXCR3 ligands, CXCL9 and CXCL10, in a Dectin-34 1/Card9-and type I and III interferon-signaling dependent manner, respectively. During 35 aspergillosis, circulating pDCs entered the lung in response to CXCR3-dependent signals. Via 36 targeted pDC ablation, we found that pDCs were essential for host defense in the presence of 37 normal neutrophil and Mo-DC numbers. Although interactions between pDC and fungal cells 38

were not detected, pDCs regulated neutrophil NADPH oxidase activity and conidial killing. 39 Thus, pDCs act as positive feedback amplifiers of neutrophil effector activity against inhaled 40 mold conidia. 41 42 (Espinosa et al., 2017; Espinosa et al., 2014). Since depletion of CCR2 + cells diminished 63 neutrophil antifungal activity, two models could explain these findings. First, CCR2 + monocytes 64 and Mo-DCs could release mediators that act directly on neutrophils to enhance antifungal 65 effector functions. Second, CCR2 + monocytes and Mo-DCs could mediate the recruitment or 66 activation of a third cellular constituent that conditions the lung inflammatory milieu 67 independent of contributions from CCR2 + monocytes and their derivatives. Here, we provide 68 evidence for the second model and identify pDCs as a third leukocyte constituent that is essential 69 for innate immune crosstalk and host defense against A. fumigatus in an otherwise immune 70 competent host. 71 The mechanism by which pDCs contribute to antifungal immunity in the lung remains an 72 open question. In vitro, human pDCs may spread over A. fumigatus hyphae to blunt fungal 73 metabolic activity, and, in rare instances, undergo a cell death process that may result in 74 extracellular traps (Loures et al., 2015; Ramirez-Ortiz et al., 2011). Mice treated with a mAb 75 (i.e., a-PDCA-1/CD317) that primarily targets pDCs in the steady state, but likely targets 76 additional leukocyte subsets under inflammatory conditions (Blasius et al., 2006), are susceptible 77

to A. fumigatus challenge. In this study, we integrate pDCs into a model of innate immune 78 crosstalk that is critical for defense against A. fumigatus in the lung. We found that fungus-79 infected Mo-DCs and neutrophils utilize Dectin-1/Card9 signaling to release CXCL9 and 80 responded to type I and type III interferon signaling to release CXCL10. These CXCR3 ligands 81 promoted pDC egress from the circulation into the infected lung. Lung CXCR3 + pDCs enhanced 82 neutrophil NADPH oxidase activity and fungal killing, preventing the formation of tissue-83 invasive hyphae and promoting sterilizing immunity. These findings integrate antifungal pDCs 84 into a model of mucosal immune defense against inhaled molds. 85

To examine specific contributions of CCR2 + monocytes and Mo-DCs to the lung 88 inflammatory milieu during A. fumigatus challenge and to eliminate potential contributions of 89 CCR2 + NK cell and CD8 + T cell subsets, we crossed the CCR2-diphtheria toxin receptor (DTR) 90 transgene to Rag2 -/interleukin-2 receptor g chain -/mice. Lung homogenates of DT-treated 91 CCR2-DTR +/-Rag2 -/interleukin-2 receptor g chain -/mice (CCR2-DTR +/-Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/-) 92 contained less CXCL10 (IP-10), CCL5 (RANTES), CCL17 (TARC), and CCL20 (MIP-3a) 93 compared to DT-treated non-transgenic Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/littermates at 36 h post-infection (pi), as 94 measured in a cytokine array (Figures S1A and S1B). 95 Because a CXCL10 polymorphism is implicated in IA susceptibility in hematopoietic cell 96 transplant recipients (Fisher et al., 2017; Mezger et al., 2008), we measured lung levels of 97 CXCL9 and CXCL10, both CXCR3 ligands, in naïve and in fungus-infected C57BL/6 mice. A. 98 fumigatus challenge induced CXCL9 and CXCL10 expression in the lung, with a peak at 48 h pi 99 ( Figure 1A ). To validate the multiplex array data, we ablated CCR2 + monocytes and Mo-DCs in 100 CCR2-DTR +/-Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/mice and observed a 50-70% reduction in lung CXCL9 and 101 CXCL10 levels at 48 h pi ( Figure S1C ). Ablation of CCR2 + monocytes and Mo-DCs in 102

body_text.text: Aspergillus fumigatus forms airborne spores (conidia) that humans typically clear in a silent 46 and asymptomatic manner. Due to the growing number of humans that live in immune 47 compromised states, A. fumigatus is the most common and lethal agent of mold pneumonia 48 worldwide (Brown et 2009). Phagocyte NADPH oxidase is central to fungal clearance, as evidenced by a 40-55% 54 lifetime prevalence of IA in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (Marciano et al., 2015) . 55
body_text.section: Introduction 45

body_text.text: Reactive oxygen species induce a regulated cell death process in neutrophil-engulfed conidia, 56 and thereby protect the respiratory tract from tissue-invasive hyphae and fungal dissemination 57 (Shlezinger et al., 2017) . 58
body_text.section: Introduction 45

body_text.text: Using targeted cell depletion strategies based on murine CCR2 promoter-dependent 59 diphtheria toxin receptor (DTR) transgene expression (Espinosa et al., 2014; Hohl et al., 2009) , 60 recent studies implicated CCR2 + inflammatory monocytes and Mo-DCs in sterilizing antifungal 61 immunity, both by direct fungal killing and by regulating the lung inflammatory milieu 62
body_text.section: Introduction 45

body_text.text: To define the cellular target of CXCR3 signaling, we measured CXCR3 expression on a 176 wide range of leukocytes. Bone marrow (BM)-resident pDCs from naïve mice and lung pDCs 177 from A. fumigatus-infected mice expressed CXCR3, unlike other myeloid cell subsets analyzed 178 ( Figure 4A ). As expected, CD4 + T cells, CD8 + T cells and NK cells expressed CXCR3 ( Figure  179 S4A), but mice that lack the lymphoid lineage (Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/-) did not exhibit heightened 180 susceptibility to A. fumigatus challenge ( Figure S4B ), as reported previously (Espinosa et al., 181 2014) . 182
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: On the basis of these results and published work (Ramirez-Ortiz et al., 2011), we 183 hypothesized that CXCR3-dependent pDC trafficking is critical for innate antifungal immunity. 184
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: In prior studies, we did not identify pDCs in lung cell suspensions due to the inclusion of 185 collagenase type IV. This preparation method degraded a pDC epitope utilized for their 186 identification ( Figure S4C ). Using a collagenase-free method to prepare single cell lung 187 suspensions, we observed that pDCs started to infiltrate A. fumigatus-infected lungs at 48 h pi, 188 with a peak at 72 h pi ( Figure 4B ). pDC lung infiltration followed the observed peak in lung 189 CXCL9 and CXCL10 levels and the peak influx of CXCL9-and CXCL10-producing innate 190 immune cells ( Figures S4D-S4F ). Cxcr3 -/mice exhibited a ~50% reduction in lung pDCs 191 ( Figure 4C ), while the number of lung monocytes, Mo-DCs, and neutrophils were similar to 192 control mice at 72 h pi ( Figures S4G-S4I ). CXCR3 surface expression was reduced on lung 193 pDCs compared to circulating pDCs, consistent with the idea that CXCR3 surface expression is 194 downregulated following engagement by CXCR3 ligands ( Figure 4A ). To examine whether 195 CXCR3 acts in series or in parallel with other chemokine receptors to mediate pDC trafficking 196 from the BM to the lung, we measured pDC surface expression of additional chemokine 197 receptors in the resting and fungus-infected state. Consistent with prior studies (Fujimura et al., 198 2015; Sawai et al., 2013; Serbina and Pamer, 2006; Swiecki et al., 2017) , we found that CCR2 is 199 expressed by lung-infiltrating pDCs ( Figure 4D ). pDC lung recruitment was attenuated by 60-200 70% in Ccr2 -/mice at 72 h pi compared to controls ( Figure 4E ). As expected (Hohl et al., 201 2009), lung monocyte and Mo-DC numbers were significantly reduced in Ccr2 -/mice (Figures 202 S4J and S4K), while lung neutrophil accumulation was not affected ( Figure S4L ). In sum, these 203 data indicate that CXCR3 and CCR2 both mediate pDC trafficking. 204 Sequential CCR2-and CXCR3-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 205
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: To determine at which steps CXCR3 and CCR2 regulate pDC trafficking, we generated 206 mixed BM chimeric mice to compare the trafficking of congenically marked gene-deficient 207 (Cxcr3 −/− or Ccr2 -/-) and gene-sufficient (Cxcr3 +/+ or Ccr2 +/+ ) pDCs ( Figure 5A ). In one model, 208
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: CXCR3 and CCR2 may act in parallel at the same trafficking step. In this scenario, the ratio of 209 gene-knockout to gene-sufficient pDCs would be increased in the same compartment for both 210 chemokine receptors, prior to the dependent trafficking step. In an alternate model, CXCR3 and 211 CCR2 may act in series at different trafficking steps. In this scenario, the ratio of gene-deficient 212 to gene-sufficient pDCs would be elevated in distinct compartments. 213
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: The ratio of Cxcr3 −/− to Cxcr3 +/+ pDCs was elevated in the blood compared to the BM and 214 lung compartments ( Figures 5B and S4A) , both during infection and at baseline ( Figure 5B and 215 Figure S5A ). These data support a model in which CXCR3 primarily, but not exclusively, 216 mediates pDCs trafficking from the circulation into the lung in A. fumigatus-infected mice. In 217 contrast to pDCs, the ratio Cxcr3 −/− to Cxcr3 +/+ neutrophils and monocytes was similar in all 218 compartments analyzed, consistent with CXCR3-independent trafficking ( Figure S5B -S5C).
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: The ratio of Ccr2 −/− to Ccr2 +/+ pDCs was elevated in BM compared to the blood and lung 220 under all conditions examined. These data are consistent with a CCR2-dependent defect in pDC 221 exit from the BM during infection ( Figure 5C ) and in the steady state ( Figure S5D ). As 222 anticipated, monocyte bone marrow egress was highly dependent on CCR2 ( Figure 5SE ), while 223 neutrophil bone marrow was not ( Figure S5F ). In sum, these data show that CCR2-and CXCR3-224 dependent signals act in series to mediate pDC entry into the circulation and pDC egress from 225 the circulation into the lung, respectively. 226
body_text.section: CXCR3-and CCR2-dependent signals mediate pDC lung recruitment 175

body_text.text: To link CXCR3 signaling to pDC-dependent antifungal immunity, our model would predict 228 that the chemokine receptor, CXCR3, and its cellular target, the pDC, are both essential for 229 innate antifungal immunity. To test this conjecture, we infected BDCA2-DTR +/-(pDC Depleter) 230 mice in which pDCs are ablated at rest and under inflammatory conditions . 231
body_text.section: Lung pDCs are essential for host defense against A. fumigatus 227

body_text.text: Following DT treatment, pDCs were depleted fully in the steady state and at 72 h pi, while lung-232 infiltrating monocytes, Mo-DCs, neutrophils, and all other leukocyte subsets examined were not 233 ( Figures 6A-6E ). In contrast to BDCA2-DTR +/mice, CCR2-DTR +/mice facilitated DT-induced 234 ablation of pDCs in addition to other known CCR2 + cells, i.e. monocytes, Mo-DCs, and NK cells 235 (Espinosa et al., 2014; Hohl et al., 2009) . 236
body_text.section: Lung pDCs are essential for host defense against A. fumigatus 227

body_text.text: To define the functional role of pDCs during A. fumigatus infection, we compared the 237 mortality, lung LDH levels, lung fungal burden and histopathology in pDC-depleted mice and in 238 littermate controls. pDC-depleted mice were more susceptible to A. fumigatus challenge than 239 control mice ( Figure 6F ) and mortality correlated with greater lung damage, as measured by 240 BAL fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels ( Figure 6G ), an increased fungal burden 241 following infection with two commonly used A. fumigatus isolates ( Figures 6H and 6I) , and a failure to control fungal germination in the lung at 72 h pi ( Figure 6J ). Importantly, pDCs did not 243 contribute to the production of CXCL9 and CXCL10 in the lung during A. fumigatus challenge, 244 as predicted by prior data (Figures 6K and 6L ). In sum, CXCR3 + pDCs were essential for innate 245 antifungal immunity in the lung after A. fumigatus challenge. 246
body_text.section: Lung pDCs are essential for host defense against A. fumigatus 227

body_text.text: To determine how pDCs shape innate antifungal immunity in the lung, we hypothesized that 248 pDCs are critical for antifungal effector functions, since lung neutrophil and Mo-DC numbers 249 were unaffected in pDC depleted mice. To test this hypothesis, we utilized the fluorescent 250
body_text.section: Lung pDCs enhance neutrophil fungicidal activity 247

body_text.text: Aspergillus reporter (FLARE) conidia that encode a dsRed viability fluorophore and are labeled 251 with an Alexa Fluor 633 tracer (AF633). FLARE conidia enable us to distinguish live 252 (DsRed + AF633 + ) and dead (DsRed -AF633 + ) conidia during cellular interactions with leukocytes 253 with single-encounter resolution ( Figure 7A ). Using the FLARE strain, we quantified leukocyte 254 conidial uptake and killing in pDC-depleted and littermate control mice. pDCs did not bind to or 255 engulf A. fumigatus conidia, as measured by acquisition of AF633 fluorescence ( Figures 7B and  256 S7A). pDC ablation did not affect lung neutrophil fungal uptake at 72 h pi compared to lung 257 neutrophils in pDC-sufficient controls ( Figures 7C and 7D ). However, the frequency of 258 neutrophils that contained live conidia was substantially increased in pDC-depleted mice 259 compared to control mice ( Figures 7C and 7E ). In other words, neutrophil-engulfed conidia were 260 more likely to be killed in control mice than in pDC-depleted mice ( Figures 7C and 7E ). pDC 261 ablation did not alter conidial uptake or significantly reduce conidial killing by monocytes and 262
body_text.section: Lung pDCs enhance neutrophil fungicidal activity 247

body_text.text: Mo-DCs at 72 h pi ( Figures 7D and 7E ). These findings indicate that pDCs enhanced neutrophil 263 fungicidal activity. 264
body_text.section: Lung pDCs enhance neutrophil fungicidal activity 247

body_text.text: Neutrophils generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) via NADPH oxidase as a primary 265 effector mechanism against A. fumigatus (Marciano et al., 2015) . Neutrophil NADPH oxidase 266 induces a regulated cell death process in A. fumigatus conidia (Shlezinger et al., 2017) . To 267 determine whether pDCs regulate the neutrophil oxidative burst in A. fumigatus-infected mice, 268
body_text.section: Lung pDCs enhance neutrophil fungicidal activity 247

body_text.text: we measured neutrophil ROS production in pDC-depleted mice. The ROS median fluorescence 269 intensity in ROS + lung neutrophils isolated from pDC-depleted mice was significantly reduced 270 compared to ROS + neutrophils isolated from littermate control mice at 72 h pi ( Figure 7E and 271 7F). These data show that lung pDCs regulate neutrophil ROS generation during A. fumigatus 272 challenge.
body_text.section: Lung pDCs enhance neutrophil fungicidal activity 247

body_text.text: Humans maintain lifelong sterilizing immunity to inhaled mold conidia. Breaches in the 275 respiratory innate immune system lead to mold pneumonia, a life-threatening disease in patients 276 with functional or numeric deficits in myeloid cell function, particularly with the loss of the 277 antifungal properties of neutrophils. In this study, we demonstrate a three-cell circuit that 278 involves pDCs, monocytes and derivative Mo-DCs, and neutrophils to regulate sterilizing 279 immunity against Aspergillus conidia. This circuit acts as a feedforward amplification 280 mechanism, by coupling fungal recognition and fungus-induced inflammation to CXCR3 281 signaling-dependent pDC recruitment in the lung. pDCs regulate neutrophil ROS induction and 282 fungal killing to mediate sterilizing immunity at the respiratory barrier. 283
body_text.section: Discussion 274

body_text.text: Our data demonstrate that conidial uptake by lung-infiltrating monocytes and Mo-DCs 284 triggered Dectin-1-and CARD9-dependent production of CXCL9 and type I and type III 285 interferon signaling-dependent production of CXCL10; the latter process was readily detectable 286 in neutrophils as well. The relative contribution of CXCL9 and CXCL10 and potential molecular 287 redundancy with regard to downstream CXCR3-dependent processes during fungal infection Cre-lox candidate gene deletion strategies is essential to test these candidates formally. 414
body_text.section: Discussion 274

body_text.text: In this study, we uncover essential functions for pDCs in innate antifungal defense that
body_text.section: Discussion 274

body_text.text: This study did not generate or analyze new datasets or codes. 559

body_text.text: Mice 561 Tween-20 at a concentration of 0.6-1.2Í10 9 cells and 50 µl of cell suspension was administered 603 via the intranasal route to mice anesthetized by isoflurane inhalation. 604
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL MODEL AND SUBJECT DETAILS 560

body_text.text: To analyze of conidia uptake and killing, FLARE conidia were used to infect mice (in vivo) or 607 co-culture with BM leukocyte (in vitro). In data analyses for a given leukocyte subset, conidial 608 uptake refers to the frequency of fungus-engaged leukocytes, i.e. the sum of dsRed + AF633 + and 609 dsRed -AF633 + leukocytes. Conidial viability within a specific leukocyte subset refers to the 610 frequency of leukocytes that contain live conidia (dsRed + AF633 + ) divided by the frequency of 611 all fungus-engaged leukocytes (dsRed + AF633 + and dsRed -AF633 + ).
body_text.section: Analysis of in vivo and in vitro conidial uptake and killing 606

body_text.text: To ablate specific cells, CCR2-DTR, CCR2-DTR, Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/-, ROSA26-iDTR Mrp8-Cre , 614 BDCA2-DTR, and non-transgenic littermate controls were injected i.p. with 10 ng/g body weight 615
body_text.section: In vivo Cell Depletion 613

body_text.text: DT on Day -1, Day 0, and Day +2 pi (Espinosa et Neutrophils were identified as CD45 + CD11b + Ly6C lo Ly6G + cells, inflammatory monocytes 627 as CD45 + CD11b + CD11c -Ly6G -Ly6C hi cells, Mo-DCs as CD45 + CD11b + CD11c + Ly6G -628
body_text.section: In vivo Cell Depletion 613

body_text.text: Ly6C hi MHC class II + cells, and pDCs as CD45 + CD11c int SiglecF -CD19 -NK1.1 -CD11b -629 B220 + SiglecH + cells. 630
body_text.section: In vivo Cell Depletion 613

body_text.text: To analyze the lung fungal burden, perfused murine lungs were homogenized using a PowerGen 631 125 homogenizer (Fisher) in 2 mL PBS, 0.025% Tween-20, and plated on Sabouraud dextrose 632 agar. To analyze cytokine levels by ELISA, whole lungs were weighed and mechanically 633 homogenized in 2 mL PBS containing protease inhibitor. To analyze cytokine levels by qRT-634 PCR, total RNA from cells was extracted with TRIzol (Invitrogen). One to two micrograms of total RNA were reverse-transcribed using High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit 636 (Applied Biosystems). TaqMan Fast Universal Master Mix (2×), TaqMan probes (Applied 637 Biosystems) for each gene were used and normalized to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate 638 dehydrogenase. Gene expression was calculated using the DDCt method relative to the naïve 639 sample. For histology, perfused lungs were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, embedded in paraffin, 640 sectioned in 4 µm slices, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) or modified Gomori 641 methenamine silver (GMS), and digitally scanned using a Zeiss Mirax Desk Scanner. Images 642 were captured from whole slide images, acquired with an Aperio ScanScope (Aperio 643 Technologies) using 5× and 20× objectives at the Molecular Cytology Core Facility (MSKCC). 644 BAL LDH and albumin levels were measured with a CytoTox96 non-radioactive cytotoxicity 645 assay kit and a BCG albumin assay kit, respectively. 646
body_text.section: In vivo Cell Depletion 613

FIGREF0.text: al., 2012; Latge and Chamilos, 2019; Lionakis and Levitz, 2018; Tischler 49 and Hohl, 2019). In humans and mice, sterilizing immunity against A. fumigatus conidia depends 50 on the action of myeloid cells, primarily neutrophils, lung-infiltrating monocytes and monocyte-51 derived DCs (Mo-DCs), as well as alveolar macrophages; all lymphoid cells are redundant for 52 host defense (Espinosa et al., 2014; Hohl et al., 2009; Latge and Chamilos, 2019; Mircescu et al., 53

FIGREF1.text: 288remains an open question for future studies. Prior studies identified a polymorphism in the 289 Cxcl10 gene as a risk factor for IA in allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant patients(Fisher et  290   al., 2017; Mezger et al., 2008). In this cohort, patients with IA had higher CXCL10 serum levels 291 than controls that did not develop IA, consistent with the idea that pulmonary fungal infection 292 induces CXCL10, similar to findings in mice in this work. Furthermore, the high-risk haplotype 293 was associated with reduced Cxcl10 mRNA expression by immature DCs (iDCs) co-cultured 294with Aspergillus germlings compared to wild-type iDCs(Mezger et al., 2008). Thus, human 295 iDCs and murine lung Mo-DCs both responded to A. fumigatus challenge by transcribing Cxcl10 296 mRNA. Although this process is generally regulated by IFN signaling in both mammalian 297 species (O'Connell et al., 2019;Ohmori et al., 1993), a recent study by Rivera and colleagues 298 defined essential roles for type I and type III, but not type II, IFNs in murine host defense against 299A. fumigatus(Espinosa et al., 2017). One model to account for these findings is that an early 300 wave of type I interferon signaling, detected as early as 6 h pi in the lung and produced primarily 301 by CCR2 + lung-infiltrating monocytes and Mo-DCs(Espinosa et al., 2017), may drive CXCL10 302 release in the lung in a paracrine or autocrine manner, as observed in this study. In accordance 303 with this model, CXCL10 lung levels that peak at 48 h pi are dependent on type I and type III 304 IFN receptor signal transduction in the Aspergillus-infected murine lung. 305Although IFN-dependent and -independent stimuli can induce CXCL9 during microbial 306 infection(Forero et al., 2019;Groom and Luster, 2011), previous studies have not directly linked 307 C-type lectin receptor signaling to fungus-induced CXCL9 production. In murine models of 308 experimental cryptococcosis with a wild-type or a recombinant vaccine strain that expresses 309 human IFN-g fungal infection led to lung CXCL9 and CXCL10 production, though the identity 310 of chemokine-producing cells was not investigated(Hole et al., 2016; Yamamoto et al., 2014). In 311 this model, Card9 -/mice had lower lung CXCL9 levels than control mice. This finding was 312 attributed to reduced lung infiltration of IFN-g-producing NK and CD4 + T cells because 313Cryptococcus-stimulated BM-DCs failed to produce either cytokine in vitro(Yamamoto et al.,  314   2014). In contrast, splenic and central nervous system (CNS)-resident Mo-DCs produced copious 315 levels of CXCL9 and CXCL10 during murine cerebral malaria(Hirako et al., 2016). Because a 316 significant fraction of CXCL9 + CXCL10 + splenic Mo-DCs contained hemozoin, a malarial 317 pigment, this study supported the idea that microbial uptake regulated CXCR3 ligand release 318 either directly or indirectly in infected cells. The authors provided evidence for indirect CXCL9 and CXCL10 regulation since their secretion was highly dependent on intact IFN-g receptor 320 signaling. In the case of respiratory A. fumigatus infection, the dual regulation of CXCL9 by 321Dectin-1/Card9 and CXCL10 by type I and type III IFN signaling indicates both direct and 322 indirect regulation of distinct CXCR3 ligands by a pathogen-associated molecular pattern 323 receptor and soluble type I and type III IFNs. 324 CXCR3 ligands have been studied extensively in the context of CD4 + and CD8 + T cell 325 trafficking in peripheral lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues, in part due to high CXCR3 326 expression on effector and memory T cell subsets, in contrast to naïve T cells(Qin et al., 2011).327 In draining LNs, antigen-activated and transferred DCs express CXCL9 and CXCL10 and 328 thereby regulate the frequency of IFN-g + CD4 + T cells, linking the CXCR3 signaling axis to the 329 formation of effector Th1 cells (Groom et al., 2012). CXCR3 facilitated the entry of effector T 330 cells into otherwise restricted sites, exemplified by CXCR3 + CD8 + T cells infiltration of the CNS 331 or genital tract during murine malaria, West Nile virus, or herpes simplex virus 2 infection 332 (Hirako et al., 2016; Nakanishi et al., 2009; Thapa and Carr, 2009; Thapa et al., 2008). During 333 bacterial infection, a study reported that CXCR3 signaling regulated neutrophil influx to the 334 infected cecum and thus controlled Salmonella extra-intestinal dissemination (Chami et al., 335 2017). In rodent models of viral (e.g., influenza virus or coronavirus) or chemical acute 336 respiratory distress syndrome, CXCL10 + lung-infiltrating neutrophils and CXCL9 + macrophages 337 mediated the recruitment of tissue-destructive CXCR3 + neutrophils; this pathologic process was 338 ameliorated in Cxcr3 -/or Cxcl10 -/mice (Ichikawa et al., 2013). During respiratory fungal 339 challenge, we did not observe CXCR3 expression on lung-infiltrating neutrophils and neutrophil 340 recruitment was unaffected in Cxcr3 -/mice compared to control mice. In more recent work in 341 the Salmonella model, infected splenic macrophages reside in T cell-sparse granulomas but are surrounded by mononuclear phagocytes that release CXCL9 and CXCL10 to recruit antigen-343 specific CXCR3 + Th1 cells for bacterial containment (Goldberg et al., 2018). Thus, CXCR3 344 ligands target both innate and adaptive immune cells in a highly context-dependent manner; this 345 process can result in microbial containment or microbe-elicited tissue damage. 346 pDCs originate in the bone marrow (BM), circulate in the blood, and traffic to lymphoid 347 and nonlymphoid tissues under homeostatic and inflammatory conditions (Fujimura et al., 2015; 348 Sozzani et al., 2010; Swiecki et al., 2017). However, the mechanism that couples microbial 349 recognition to pDC accumulation at peripheral sites has remained poorly understood. During 350 respiratory fungal infection, neither CCR2 + monocytes nor CCR2neutrophils had the capacity 351 to respond to CXCR3 ligands because these cells do not express CXCR3. Thus, the recruitment 352 of lung-infiltrating monocytes and pDCs occurs via a pathway that bifurcated after the initial 353 CCR2-dependent egress from the bone marrow reservoir. Although the precise cues that regulate 354 the CXCR3-independent entry of circulating monocytes into the fungus-infected lung remain 355 unknown, integrin-mediated mechanisms enable monocytic influx into hepatic foci of Listeria 356 monocytogenes during systemic infection (Shi et al., 2010). 357 During other types of lung infections, e.g. influenza and RSV, pDCs traffic to the lungs and 358 draining LNs of mice (Langlois and Legge, 2010; Smit et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2006) via 359 pathways that are distinct compared to conventional DCs (Sawai et al., 2013; Sozzani et al., 360 2010). For example, pDC LN trafficking during murine influenza is regulated primarily by L-361 selectin (CD62L), with contributions from CXCR3 and CXCR4. Further pDC positioning within 362 the LN is mediated by CCR7 and the release of pDC-derived CXCR3 ligands to enable the 363 formation of clusters of pDCs that interact and activate cells of the adaptive immune system 364 (Krug et al., 2002). In contrast, we did not observe pDC-dependent release of CXCL9 and 365 CXCL10 in the Aspergillus-infected lung, consistent with the model that pDC recruitment cues 366 depends on heterologous myeloid cells. Beyond CXCR3, L-selectin, and CXCR4, the E-selectin 367 ligands, b1 and b2 integrins, CCR5, CCR7, and the chemerin receptor ChemR23 have been 368 implicated in pDC trafficking during states of inflammation (Diacovo et al., 2005; Kohrgruber et 369 al., 2004; Sozzani et al., 2010; Vanbervliet et al., 2003; Wendland et al., 2007), though it has 370 remained unclear how individual cues cooperate to guide distinct pDC trafficking steps, and 371 what the relative strength of individual cues is for defined tissue destinations and types of 372 inflammatory stimuli. The sequential requirements for CCR2 and CXCR3 signaling in distinct 373 pDC trafficking steps during respiratory A. fumigatus infection provides a combinatorial model, 374 in which a more general cue for myeloid cell bone marrow egress (i.e., CCR2 that acts on 375 monocytes and pDCs) is combined with a more specific, pDC-targeted cue (i.e., CXCR3). The 376 latter cue emanates primarily from CCR2 + Mo-DCs that were not equipped to control fungal 377 tissue invasion or license the full spectrum of neutrophil antifungal activity per se. 378 pDCs were functionally characterized as mediators of antiviral defense (Assil et al., 2019; 379 Swiecki and Colonna, 2010). Recent studies have expanded their role to anti-bacterial (e.g., 380 Legionella pneumophila, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus) (Ang et al., 2010; 381 Crother et al., 2012; Parcina et al., 2013) and to anti-fungal defense (Ang et al., 2010; Hole et al., 382 2016). pDC-mediated antiviral responses are stimulated upon physical contact with infected cells 383 (Assil et al., 2019). pDCs adhere to infected cells via α L β 2 integrin/ICAM-1 interactions, during 384 which viral RNA is transferred to pDCs, leading to IFN production via the nucleic acid sensor 385 TLR7. This process activates type I IFN-dependent antiviral programs in infected tissues. During 386 respiratory fungal infection, lung-infiltrating pDCs do not interact directly with Aspergillus 387 conidia, but instead regulate neutrophils ROS induction. Our study does not exclude the possibility that Aspergillus-or host cell-derived nucleic acids activate pDCs in the lung in situ. 389 Prior work has demonstrated that Aspergillus-derived unmethylated CpG sequences can activate 390 TLR9 signaling in vitro (Herbst et al., 2015; Ramirez-Ortiz et al., 2008). Alternatively, pDCs 391 may recognize fungal Dectin-2/CLEC4N or Dectin-3/CLEC4E ligands (Loures et al., 2015; 392 Maldonado and Fitzgerald-Bocarsly, 2017; Preite et al., 2018). In patients with systemic lupus 393 erythematosus, neutrophil-derived extracellular traps (NETs) activate pDCs by releasing DNA-394 protein complexes, resulting in TLR9-dependent release of pathologic type I IFNs during 395 autoimmunity (Garcia-Romo et al., 2011; Lande et al., 2011). While A. fumigatus conidia are 396 poor inducers of NETosis, products of germination, specifically hyphae that are too large to be 397 phagocytosed, are potent stimuli for NETosis (Bianchi et al., 2009; Bruns et al., 2010; Gibrat et 398 al., 1989). Thus, pDC activation in the fungus-infected lung likely occurs by multiple, yet 399 undefined mechanisms. 400 The molecular basis for pDC-neutrophil crosstalk represents an important area of future 401 investigation. Two non-exclusive models are likely operative. First, pDCs may form direct 402 contact with neutrophils after arriving at the site of infection. In this model, an individual pDC 403 would interact with many neutrophils since neutrophils are ~100 times more prevalent in the 404 lung at 48 h pi compared to pDCs. The relative paucity of pDCs, compared to other infiltrating 405 myeloid cells (i.e., neutrophils, Mo-DCs), makes it unlikely that direct pDC-mediated 406 fungistasis, observed at high effector to target cell ratios in the test tube, is physiologically 407 significant in the fungus-infected lung (Loures et al., 2015; Maldonado and Fitzgerald-Bocarsly, 408 2017). Second, either fungus-triggered or host cell-triggered pDC activation may result in the 409 release of soluble mediators that boost neutrophil fungicidal activity. Previous studies have 410 identified GM-CSF, type I IFN, and type III IFN as important regulators of neutrophil NADPH 411 oxidase activity during respiratory A. fumigatus and B. dermatiditis challenge (Espinosa et al., 412 2017; Hernandez-Santos et al., 2018; Kasahara et al., 2016). The development of pDC-restricted 413

FIGREF2.text: 415 cannot be compensated by the presence of other myeloid cells, including neutrophils, monocytes, 416 and Mo-DCs. In fact, fungus-engaged Mo-DCs and neutrophils harness pDCs as a feedforward 417 amplification mechanism to enhance innate antifungal activity in the lung by coupling fungal 418 recognition and fungus-induced inflammation to the CXCR3 signaling-dependent recruitment of 419 pDCs into the fungus-infected lung. In the lung pDCs regulate neutrophil ROS induction, a 420 process that induces a regulated cell death process in mold conidia (Shlezinger et al., 2017). Our 421 findings indicate that pDC recovery following administration of chemotherapy and in bone 422 marrow transplant recipients may represent an important variable that affects infectious 423 susceptibility not just to viral, but also to fungal pathogens. Recent studies in bone marrow 424 transplant patients indicate that donor pDC reconstitution in the recipient is associated with 425 favorable clinical outcomes, including non-relapse mortality from unrelated donors (Goncalves 426 et al., 2015; Waller et al., 2019; Waller et al., 2014). These data raise the possibility that pDC 427 recovery in bone marrow transplant patients may be important for controlling systemic fungal 428 infections. Further studies to decipher the mechanistic role of pDCs in antifungal immunity is 429 likely to inform strategies to harness these cells for prophylactic or therapeutic gain in vulnerable 430 patient populations. We thank 435 Franck Barrat, and Iliyan Iliev (both Weill Cornell Medical College), and members of the Hohl 436 laboratory for insightful discussions. FIGREF3.text: CCR2 + Mo-DCs and neutrophils produce CXCL9 and CXCL10 during A. plots of RFP (CXCL9) and BFP (CXCL10) expression in indicated lung 455 leukocytes isolated from Rex3 Tg ® C57BL/6.SJL BM chimeric mice at baseline (naïve, top 456 row) and 48 h pi with 3 × 10 7 CEA10 conidia (infected, bottom row). The blue and purple gates 457 indicate the frequency of BFP + (CXCL9 + ) and BFP + RFP + (CXCL9 + CXCL10 + ) graphs indicate the frequency of CXCL9 -CXCL10 + and CXCL9 + CXCL10 + neutrophils, 460 monocytes, Mo-DCs, and pDCs and (F) the cellular identity of all CXCL9 -CXCL10 + (top) and 461 CXCL9 + CXCL10 + lung leukocytes (bottom) at 48 h pi. 462 (G-H) Lung CXCL9 and CXCL10 levels in DT-treated ROSA26-iDTR Mrp8-Cre ® C57BL/6.SJL 463 (Neutrophil Depleter) or non-Cre iDTR littermates → C57BL/6.SJL (Control) BM chimeric 464 mice (n = 10) at 48 h pi with 3-4 × 10 7 heat-killed swollen CEA10 conidia. Data from 2 465 independent experiments were pooled. 466 (A-C, G, H) Dots represent individual mice and data were presented as mean ± SEM. Statistical 467 analysis: (A) Kruskal-Wallis test, timepoints compared to t = 0 h, (B, C, G, H) Mann-Whitney 468test. See alsoFigure S1.

FIGREF4.text: Fungal Uptake and Dectin-1/Card9 and IFN signaling regulate lung CXCL9 and 470 CXCL10 levels during A. fumigatus infection. 471 (A) Representative flow cytometry plots and bar graphs (B-E) that indicate the frequency of 472 RFP + (CXCL9 + ; red bar in B-C), RFP -(CXCL9 -; gray bar in B-C), BFP + (CXCL10 + ; blue bar, in 473 D-E), and BFP -(CXCL10 -; gray bar in D-E) bystander and fungus-engaged leukocytes isolated 474 from (A, left column) naïve or (A, middle and right column, B-E) infected Rex3 Tg ® 475 C57BL/6.SJL BM chimeric mice (n = 7) with 3 × 10 7 AF633-labeled CEA10 conidia. The solid 476 black gates in (A) indicate bystander neutrophils, while the solid blue gates indicate fungus-477 engaged leukocytes. The dashed line in the black and blue gate indicate CXCL9 + and CXCL9 -478 (top quadrants) leukocytes, and CXCL10 + and CXCL10 -(bottom quadrants) leukocytes. 479 (F) Lung CXCL9 and (G) CXCL10 levels in naïve wild-type (WT, n = 5) and in WT (n = 10), 480 Clec7a -/-(n = 8), Card9 -/-(n = 7), Ifnar1 -/-(n = 9), and Ifnlr -/-(n = 9) mice 48 h pi with 3 × 10 7 481 CEA10 conidia. Data were pooled from 2 independent experiments. 482 (B-G) Dots represent individual mice and data are presented as mean ± SEM. Statistical analysis: CXCR3 is critical for anti-Aspergillus defense. lung fungal burden, (C) bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL) LDH level, and (D) 488 BAL albumin levels in C57BL/6 and Cxcr3 -/mice 48 h pi with 3 × 10 7 CEA10 conidia. (A-D) 489 Dots represent individual mice and data were pooled from 2-4 experiments and presented as 490 mean ± SEM. Statistical analysis: Mann-Whitney test. See also Figure S3.

FIGREF5.text: CXCR3 + pDCs traffic to A. fumigatus-infected lungs. 492 (A) CXCR3 surface expression in BM (top row) and lung (bottom row) leukocytes isolated from 493 WT (black lines) or Cxcr3 -/mice (purple lines). 494 (B) Lung (blue filled dots) and BM (open black dots) pDC numbers at baseline and indicated 495 times pi with 3 × 10 7 CEA10 conidia (n = 5). 496 (C) Lung pDC numbers in WT (open black dots) and Cxcr3 -/mice (open purple dots) at 72 surface expression in BM and lung pDCs in WT (black lines) or Ccr2 -/mice (green 499 lines). 500 (E) Lung pDC numbers in WT (open black dots) and Ccr2 -/mice (open green dots) at 72 h pi , C, E) Data from 2-3 experiments were pooled and expressed as mean ± SEM. Statistical 503 analysis: Mann-Whitney test. See alsoFigure S4.

FIGREF6.text: Sequential CCR2-and CXCR3-dependent signals mediate lung pDC recruitment. 505 (A) Experimental scheme to generate mixed bone marrow chimeric mice and compare the 506 trafficking of Cxcr3 -/-, Ccr2 -/-, and WT pDCs during A. fumigatus infection. 507 (B, C) Relative frequencies of (B) Cxcr3 -/-(open purple bars) and Cxcr3 +/+ (WT, open black 508 bars) and (C) Ccr2 -/-(open green bars) and Ccr2 +/+ (WT, open black bars) pDCs in the BM, 509 blood, and lung of mixed BM chimeric mice 72 h pi. Data from 2-3 experiments were pooled 510 and expressed as mean ± SEM. Statistical analysis: Mann-Whitney test. See also Figure S5.

FIGREF7.text: pDCs are critical for anti-Aspergillus defense. 512 (A) Representative flow cytometry plots of B220 + Siglec-H + pDCs and (B) lung pDC, (C) lung 513 monocyte, (D) lung Mo-DC, and (E) lung neutrophil numbers in DT-treated pDC Depleter mice 514 (BDCA2-DTR; open red symbols) and non-Tg littermate controls (open black symbols) BAL LDH levels and (H) fungal burden of DT-treated pDC Depleter (open red symbols; histopathology (top row, hematoxylin and eosin stain, scale bar 800µm; middle row, 523 Gomori methenamine silver stain, scale bar 800µm; bottom row, GMS, scale bar 200µm) of DT-524 treated pDC Depleter (right column; n = 6) or non-Tg littermates (Control, left column; CXCL9 and (L) lung CXCL10 levels in DT-treated pDC Depleter mice (red symbols) 527 and non-Tg littermate controls (black symbols) at 72 h pi with 3 × 10 7 CEA10 conidia. 528 (B-L) Data were pooled from 2-3 independent experiments and expressed as mean ± SEM. 529 Statistical analysis: Mann-Whitney test. See also Figure S6.

R1 denotes neutrophils that contain live conidia, R2 denotes neutrophils 538 that contain killed conidia. 539 (D and E) The plots show neutrophil, monocyte, and Mo-DC (D) conidial uptake (R1 + R2) ± 540 SEM and (E) conidial viability (R1/ (R1 + R2) ± SEM in indicated lung leukocytes isolated from 541 DT-treated pDC Depleter (red symbols) and non-Tg littermates (black symbols) 72 h pi with 3 × 542 10 7 FLARE conidia. 543 (F) Representative plot and (G) mean ± SEM neutrophil ROS production in cells isolated from 544 DT-treated pDC Depleter (right panel) and non-Tg littermates (left panel) 72 h pi with 3 from 2 experiments were pooled. (F, G) Data are representative of 2 experiments. (D, 547 E, G) Dots represent individual mice and data are expressed as mean ± SEM.

FIGREF9.text: and requests for resources or reagents should be directed to the Lead 554 Contact, Tobias M. Hohl (hohlt@mskcc.org). 555

FIGREF10.text: Cxcr3 -/-, C57BL/6 (CD45.2 +/+ ), BDCA2-DTR mice were purchased from Jackson Laboratories 562 (JAX: 014176). Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/mice (Stock No. 4111) were purchased from Taconic. Ccr2 -/-563 (JAX: 004999) (Serbina and Pamer, 2006), Ifnar1 -/-(JAX: 32045) (Jia et al., 2009), and Ifnlr -/-564 (Lin et al., 2016) mice were provided by Dr. Eric Pamer (University of Chicago) and Dr. Sergei 565 Kotenko (Rutgers), respectively. Bones from REX3 Tg (CXCL9-Red Red fluorescent 566 protein/CXCL10-Blue fluorescent protein reporter) mice (Groom et al., 2012) were provided by 567 Dr. Andrew Luster (Massachusetts General Hospital). Clec7a -/mice (Saijo et al., 2007) were 568 provided by Dr. Shinobu Saijo (University of Tokyo). Card9 -/mice (Hsu et al., 2007b) were 569 provided by Dr. Xin Lin (Tsinghua University). MRP8-Cre-IRES/GFP and Oct-4/rtTA mice 570 were crossed to generate ROSA26-iDTR Mrp8-Cre mice. C57BL/6 and C57BL/6.SJL mice were 571 crossed to generate CD45.1 + CD45.2 + recipient mice for mixed BM chimeras. CCR2-DTR +/-572 (Hohl et al., 2009) and non-transgenic littermates on the Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/background were 573 maintained on amoxicillin-and Vitamin E-containing chow. All experiments with CCR2-DTR, 574 CCR2-DTR Rag2 -/-Il2rg -/and BDCA2-DTR mice used co-housed littermate controls. For 575 experiments in which the breeding strategy did not yield littermate controls, gene-knockout mice 576 were co-housed with C57BL/6 mice for 14 days prior to infection, whenever possible. All mouse 577 strains were bred and housed in the MSKCC or Rutgers Research Animal Resource Center under 578 specific pathogen-free conditions. All animal experiments were conducted with sex-and age-579 matched mice and performed with MSKCC or Rutgers Institutional Animal Care and Use 580 Committee approval. Animal studies complied with all applicable provisions established by the 581 Animal Welfare Act and the Public Health Services Policy on the Humane Care and Use of 582 Laboratory Animals. 583 Generation of Bone Marrow Chimeric Mice 584 For single BM chimeras, CD45.1 + C57BL/6.SJL recipients were lethally irradiated (900cG), 585 reconstituted with either 2-5 × 10 6 CD45.2 + Rex3-Tg, CD45.2 + ROSA26-iDTR Mrp8-Cre , or 586 CD45.2 + non-Cre iDTR littermates BM cells. For mixed BM chimeras, CD45.1 + CD45.2 + 587 recipients were irradiated and reconstituted with a 1:1 mixture of CD45.1 + C57BL/6.SJL and 588 CD45.2 + Cxcr3 -/or CD45.2 + Ccr2 -/-BM cells. After BM transplantation, recipient mice received 589 400 µg/ml enrofloxacin in the drinking water for 21 days to prevent bacterial infections and 590 rested for 6-8 weeks prior to experimental use. 591 Aspergillus fumigatus culture and Infection Model 592 A. fumigatus Af293, Af293-dsRed (Jhingran et al., 2012), and CEA10 (Girardin et al., 1993) 593 strains were cultured on glucose minimal medium slants at 37 o C for 4-7 days prior to harvesting 594 conidia for experimental use. To generate FLARE conidia, briefly, 7 × 10 8 Af293-dsRed conidia 595 were rotated in 10 µg/ml Biotin XX, SSE in 1 ml of 50 mM carbonate buffer (pH 8.3) for 2 hr at 596 4 ºC, incubated with 20 µg/ml Alexa Fluor 633 succinimidyl ester at 37 ºC for 1 h, resuspended 597 in PBS and 0.025% Tween 20 for use within 24 hr (Heung et al., 2015; Jhingran et al., 2016; 598 Jhingran et al., 2012). To generate morphologically uniform heat-killed swollen conidia, 599 5Í10 6 /ml conidia were incubated at 37 o C for 14 hours in RPMI-1640 and 0.5 µg/ml 600 voriconazole and heat killed at 100 ºC for 30 minutes (Hohl et al., 2005). To infect mice with 30-601 60 million live or heat-killed A. fumigatus cells, conidia were resuspended in PBS, 0.025% 602

FIGREF11.text: lung suspensions were prepared for flow cytometry as described in (Hohl et al., 619 2009), with minor modifications. Briefly, perfused murine lungs were placed in a gentle 620 MACS™ C tube and mechanically homogenized in 5 ml RPMI-1640, 10% FBS, and 0.1 mg/ml 621 DNAse using a gentle MACS™ Octo Dissociator (Miltenyi Biotecc) in the absence of 622 collagenase. Lung cell suspensions were lysed of RBCs, enumerated, and stained with 623 fluorophore-conjugated antibodies prior to flow cytometric analysis on a BD LSR II or flow 624 cytometric sorting on a BD Aria, flow plot analysis was performed using FlowJo v.

FIGREF12.text: ROS levels were measured in cells using CM-H2DCFDA [5-(and 6-) chloromethyl-648 2,7-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate, acetyl ester] as described in (Espinosa et al., 2017; 649 Hackstein et al., 2012). Briefly, single cell lung suspensions were incubated with 1µM CM-650 H2DCFDA in Hanks' balanced salt solution at 37º C for 45 min according to manufacturer's 651 instruction, and analyzed by flow cytometry. 652 QUANTIFICATION AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS 653 Data are representative of at least 2 independent experiments, as indicated. All results are 654 expressed as mean (± SEM), unless stated otherwise. The Mann-Whitney test was used for 655 comparisons of two groups, unless noted otherwise. The Kruskal-Wallis test was used for multi-656 group comparisons, unless noted otherwise. Survival data was analyzed by long-rank test. All 657 statistical analyses were performed with GraphPad Prism software, v8.2.0.

FIGREF13.text: pDCs do not bind to or engulf A. fumigatus conidia. Related to Figure 7. 1124 (A) AF633 fluorescence intensity in indicated BM leukocytes co-cultured for 24 h with FLARE 1125 (blue line) or AF633-unlabeled conidia (MOI = 5). 1126
